awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Exploring Galaxy Evolution at High Resolution with Gravitational Lensing and ALMA
awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies the growth of massive galaxies in the first few billion years after the Big Bang.  The target galaxies are magnified by "gravitational lensing," the bending of light around intervening galaxies, which allows them to be detected more easily and studied in greater detail than other galaxies at similar distance.  The primary data come from the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA).  With these and other data, the team will determine how these galaxies form stars so rapidly and shut down their formation so quickly, look for evidence of black hole growth in the galaxies, determine the number of such galaxies in the Universe to see how they affect the overall history of cosmic star formation, and test the modern cosmological paradigm by exploring their lensing in great detail.  This award will support the teaching of astronomy through examples from this research to fifth grade classes in Illinois, hands-on radio astronomy technology experiences for high school students in Arizona, and training of undergraduate and graduate students in advanced techniques of radio astronomy and interferometry.

The project will pursue several goals using gravitationally lensed galaxies discovered by the South Pole Telescope:  (1) determine the triggering mechanisms for the most intense star formation events in the high redshift Universe, (2) study the regulation and termination of star formation by observing gas dynamics and outflows, (3) study the assembly of massive elliptical galaxies by determining stellar masses, star formation rates, and gas content in such galaxies at very high redshift, (4) explore the coevolution of black hole accretion and stellar mass assembly in these objects, (5) measure metal enrichment with far-infrared atomic lines, (6) determine the space density of these extreme starbursts and connect them to state of the art galaxy formation simulations, and (7) identify substructure in the halos lensing these galaxies to test the predictions of  current cosmology models.  These goals are largely achievable based on the data already promised in ALMA cycles 3 and 4 using the advanced interferometric analysis tools that have been built up over the past several years.  The team incorporates both observers and theorists to ensure that the lessons derived from these high-resolution views of the early Universe can be compared against and fed back into state-of-the-art galaxy formation simulations.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the process by which massive galaxies form in the first quarter of cosmic history. The targets of this work are some of the most luminous objects in the sky at far-infrared wavelengths, discovered due to their extreme brightness at wavelengths around 1mm. Of nearly 100 such objects discovered by the South Pole Telescope (SPT) in a survey of 1/8th of the southern sky, nearly all are magnified by the gravity of an intervening galaxy. This provides exceptional opportunities to understand these extremely distant objects. 


Intellectual Merit Outcomes: 

Our understanding of galaxy formation has some important holes in it. One of these is the process through which galaxies that are actively forming stars cease to do so. They may simply consume all their raw material, the cool gas and dust of the interstellar medium, but it seems that a feedback process must actively stop star formation. An important outcome of this work was to reveal the ubiquity of outflowing cool gas in rapidly star forming galaxies, almost certainly driven off by the intensity of the star formation process. Several papers from this project showed these outflows in great detail. Another uncertainty is the variation of physical conditions in galaxies of various masses and star formation rates. This project addressed this in many ways. Using our sample of galaxies we assembled a composite spectrum that represents an average for this class of massive, rapidly star forming objects in the early universe, which we compare to other classes of galaxies. We were also able to subdivide our sample into warmer and cooler galaxies to see how other properties changed with the dust temperature. We also used the sample to determine the distribution of our rare galaxies across cosmic time, and understand their contribution to cosmic star formation, as compared to other galaxy classes. We also explored the conditions in exceptional individual galaxies, particularly the very earliest ones in our samples. Most remarkably, we found that even in massive galaxies observed when the universe was only 6% of its current age, the cycle of star formation and death seems to have had time to fill the most massive galaxies with the rich mix of elements that we see in our own Milky Way galaxy 13 billion years later. In our most distant pair of galaxies, we also observed the chaotic process of early galaxy formation. These galaxies were revealed to divide into numerous clumps of vigorous star formation, more active than almost anything in the local universe, rather than calm and orderly disk galaxies, as has been proposed for many distant objects. We were also able to explore the formation of more massive structures, the progenitors of galaxy clusters, to understand how they assemble their core galaxies and large stellar masses. Much of this work motivated successful proposals to use JWST, and first results from our observations will be released shortly.


Broader Impacts Outcomes:

Under this project we have provided training for undergraduates and graduate students at several institutions. Two women completed their astrophysics PhDs under this project, one each at Illinois and Arizona. A third PhD student at Illinois was directly supported, and four other PhD students also published work under this project through our multi-university and multi-national collaboration. Several undergraduates were also involved, including one who led a paper. Furthermore, we have made use of our data to teach students at many levels about the important methods by which we make our observations, primarily radio interferometry. Data from this project has been used for exercises in both undergraduate and graduate courses, and as examples for instructing professional astronomers in the finer points of using interferometers. Finally, the unusual nature of the objects we study has led to significant attention in scientist-facing and mass media over the course of the project, giving us the opportunity to convey the highlights of this work to wider audiences.
